A great many historians today agree and acknowledge that the numbers were grossly inflated by hawkish politicians and newspapers of the day. To get a real account of this and any other war for that matter, it's best to seek it out from a neutral historian. They are harder to find than one would think. Not to mention that, "neutral" history, is in the ear of the beholder. When a Conservative tells the stories, it's more on the accomplishments of the US in all her glory. With that, you'll hear the history in a more bias way that no faults are usually highlighted even though the faults are just as, if not more important than the victories. It's a noble attempt, but we must learn from the mistakes or we're destined to repeat them. On the other hand, (being the "left" if you will), you can spot a Liberal rather easy. The focus is more on the mistakes of US, along with personal opinion commentary on how horrible the Americans were at every turn and put in a matter of fact kind of way. Like the Conservative way, the Liberls history may be accurate in many ways, but it's mixed in with so much personal negative banter, after the lesson, one would almost seem embarrassed by by it. The history lesson should be taught with only facts. Everyone must know that every single place on earth has a dark history. Some worse than others and some still committing the worst kind today. The important part is the changes made over time that has moved towards changing and making things better from the things our ancestors committed against others. Something we as a civilized nation today, can't erase from time. It's embedded in our history forever. If these things can't be forgiven, then what chance do we have as people to move forward through time and grow. Until history can be told in completely unbiased manner, one side will just highlight the positive while the other side can't let go of the negative. That in of itself keeps the division alive and well in America and the more each side pushes, the farther the division becomes. America has faults most definitely, however, until one side admits them and the other side stops dwelling on them, it will continue to grow. We can only control today. Yesterday has gone and anyone that's actually guilty of those atrocities of our past are long gone. What's left is many good people stuck in the past that continues to haunt us all, from all walks of life, when we should be coming together to work towards a better future with real honest compromises in order to move forward.

The British were engaged in Europe fighting Napoleon, with the War of 1812 way down the list of priorities.   Once Napoleon was beaten the Royal Navy sent fleets to Washington and New Orleans. When the American marines in Washington saw the British fleet arriving, they fled. The President barely escaped before the Shropshire Light Infantry reached the White House. The British found his dinner had been served being still hot. They ate his meal and burned the White House down. The war effectively ended on that point. The American victory at New Orleans, after peace was declared, with British troops readied for a counter-attack, was inconsequential to the peace treaty that the British awarded the USA.

The peace treaty was very generous to the USA who could have been taken back into the British Empire. The British proposed a line was drawn between Canada and the US, with the USA given everything south of that line, even territory the British had previously claimed. The Americans agreed with the British not to cross north of the line.

The USA shows no shame or embarrassment about abandoning the American capital, allowing the White House to be burned down. Leading American officials immediately ran to Europe seeking a peace treaty as soon as the British fleet arrived in Washington. Prior to the arrival of the fleet the USA was only fighting against the Canadian militia. The Americans could not conquer Canada even though the British were preoccupied with Napoleon in Europe.

The USA should be embarrassed by the war of 181, by siding with Napoleon and attempting to conquer Canada. The Americans hoped that Napoleon would conquer Europe defeating the British Empire. Napoleon assured the USA that he had no desires on controlling the continent of America when he sold the territory in the Louisiana Purchase. Napoleon gave all of the territories France claimed in America for near nothing. The USA would have been offered to buy Canada from Napoleon If he had conquered the British.

America stated that American countries should not be ruled by Europeans overseas being stated in the Monroe doctrine, unable to enforce it. It was the British who enforced the Monroe doctrine for the USA. The British agreed that the USA should govern themselves. The British rewarded the USA for losing the war, not being brought back into the British empire. America has no shame. They did not have to be engaged in the wars between the British and French in Europe by fighting with Canada in America. Both colonial America and the United States fought against Canada simply because France was fighting Britain in Europe.

Most American historians claim the war was a draw, which is ludicrous.  The USA totally failed to achieve its aims, while the British succeeded is achieving theirs.

The US accomplished much in this war. Britain, who had been rather aggressive toward the US in general was relegated to relatively good behavior after this tussle. US manufacturing saw a sharp rise in capacity due to the British blockade which prevented the normal flow of imported manufacturing goods. Britain's provocative encouragement of the Indians in the northwest resulted in a resolution in the favor of America that might have taken quite some time to resolve otherwise. The British military presence in Canada was severely and permanently truncated in the aftermath of the war. The war also sparked a strong period of unity among Americans.

Britain on the other hand lost a considerable amount of money and lives on the endeavor, and pretty much came away with nothing more than being able to say "we burned a house down" from it. Canada got to say "they tried to invade us but it didn't work", which is nice to soothe the inferiority complex many of them have to this day, I suppose, but they had nothing of substance to claim from the affair.

Ok, this is a lengthy comment, but I like your work. I encourage my students to listen to your commentaries. Still, I have some thoughts. First, I thought the Iroquois federation (five tribes) who won against the Algonquin federation (9 tribes) in what I think it was called the Great Beaver Wars won the land west of the colonies. If I remember correctly, it was negotiated by the French in the Great Peace Treaty. After they settled that war with the Great Peace Treaty, the Iroquois sold this conquered land/Indian territory west of the colonies to the British Empire in which American Colonists were a part of at that time and so making it British/Colonist lands since that was purchased land. Is that correct? When the British and the French returned to war, the allies of the French (Algonquin Federation) called the Great Peace treaty null and void and decided to take back the land they had already lost to the Iroquois. The British (and their allies including Indian allies the Iroquois) again won that land in the French Indian war and made treaties, but the British (and their Indian allies) then lost it this land to the American Colonists with their loss in the American Revolution.

The idea that people cannot purchase land is interesting since Native Americans and their federations at that time did sell land to both British and French Colonist. But the idea that to sell land the same " as air" which cannot be sold is something that is mentioned as a quote by Indians of that time. However, land was actually sold by Indians of that time. Iroquois sold land to Britain, I believe New Hampshire purchased land as well from the Native Americans. French documents also show the same kind of purchases. Native Americans selling land and saying that cant be done causes a huge discrepancy in the validity of such an argument. Not many people can be taken seriously if on one hand they say it is not for sale, but on the other hand they sell it and take money for it. The morality of in can obviously argued, but the history report should address that such acts happened or it creates a bias instead of a presentation of historical facts.

Also, why toss in a comment that stated that the slaves were counted as 3/5th of a human? The clause is actually interpreted as 3 out of 5 slaves which would count as a vote, and it was a compromise to limit Southern domination in the numbers of representatives in Congress. For a person of that time to say that a slave is only 3/5th of a person, goes against other claims of that time that slaves were not people but property as the Southern elites defined them as well as opposes the beliefs of the Northern abolitionists which protested that slaves were people. I believe too that in the argument for slaves actually having a count in Congress was also due in part because some were free men and owned land.

You are right on the failures of our country in some ways as men are not perfect and we can learn from this and should, but some of this appears to have a bias against history itself. It is good to point out truths, but it seems all sides of truth should be noted.

Your account of the Battle of Tippecanoe is overly simplified (ok time constraints), woefully inacurrate, and gives the completely wrong impression of the events that took place.

Tecumpseh was out of town gathering Native Americans to sign a treaty of unity to form an Indian Nation to be recognized by the U.S. Government when his brother Prophet took it upon himself to gather their forces and begin attacking the nearby settlement from their encampment at Prophetstown.

In response to this newly increase aggression Harrison marched up here with an army to address the issue and see if they couldn't talk these folks into settling down. Upon arrival they were greeted by some Native Americans who told them where to camp for the night and that Prophet would see them in the morning. At 4am they were ambushed, but Harrison had anticipated it and the men were (somewhat) ready for the attack. Casualties were high, but much higher on the Native American side because they were under the belief that Prophet (who was singing on a large rock nearby) would make them invulnerable... but they weren't.

Once the sun came up Harrison and his army found that the survivors had fled their encampment, so they burned it down to discourage further gathering.

Had Prophet just kept the encampment safe and quiet until Tecumpseh got back, the Native Americans may have eventually formed an official united government and much of North America might now a part of that nation instead of the USA.

Like the previous video on the French and Indian War, this one is rife with errors. Here are just a few:

1. Canada does NOT have "excellent healthcare." Government healthcare has proven to be a terrible system just about everywhere it's been tried (i.e. nearly every Western country other than the US). People have to wait months or even years to get the care they need, even if it is a medical emergency.

2. "Why isn't there more to celebrate" about American history? As a matter of fact sir, there is much to celebrate about American history. Granted, not everything in our history is worth celebrating, but that doesn't mean there's nothing either.

3. The British Invasion began in 1964, not 1961. Few Americans had ever heard of the Beatles or any other British rock band until some time around mid- to late 1963, and it wasn't until early 1964 that British musicians really began to take off in the States (and even then, plenty of Americans continued to chart alongside them).

4. Under the Constitution, slaves were not "counted as three fifths of a human." Rather, three fifths of the slave population was to be counted in the Census, in addition to free persons, to determine taxation and apportionment of the House. This provision had nothing to do with the value of people or races, and was a compromise that actually minimized the influence of Southern slave states. While it's true that they got more representation than they would've had if slaves hadn't been included, counting only three fifths of the slaves gave them less than counting all the slaves would have. Ironically, it was this provision that allowed slavery to eventually be abolished, as it gave the Southern states less political clout than they would've had if the entire slave population had been included. (Nor were the Federalists necessarily anti-slavery either; Roger Taney, the Chief Justice who issued what is widely considered the majority opinion in the Dred Scott case, began his political career as a Federalist; Charles Pinckney, whom the Federalists nominated for president in 1804 and 1808, hailed from South Carolina and took an indifferent stance toward slavery.)

I don't think a lot of Canadians here know about the special terms which ended the war of 1812.  You may have burned the capital, but Britain essentially refocused its attention after the war on Europe, leaving the Canadians in a very vulnerable position as they were (and are) weaker demographically and militarily.  This is why the result wasn't really a decisive "win" for Canadians.  The after math of the war began the Canadian tradition of trying to get the Americans to see them as friends, because they understood that round two would likely not be as kind to them as round one was, should Washington ever refocus it's attention on North America.   It was a bungled war, but not a decisive defeat for the US or its interests.  Most importantly the US was able to solidify its financial, cultural, and military control of the Mississippi River with the battle of New Orleans; which essentially gave it dominion over the easiest developed and most productive land and paved the way for policies such as the Monroe Doctrine.

What the Americans didn't understand was that British Canada was created by the Seven Years War, whereas our Revolution came about over British attempts to make us pay for that war. The Canadians were more than happy to be British subjects.     When Wellington was asked to take command of British forces in America he replied "That which appears to me to be wanting in America is not a General, or General Officers and troops, but a naval superiority on the Lakes; without it I could do
little more than sign a peace treaty which might as well be signed now. "     There were Englishmen supporting the US cause during the war, and when it was over feelings were mixed. Much of Parliament were saying the Americans had accomplished nothing, to which Englishman William Cobbett wrote "Is it nothing to have proved that her Government, though free as air, is perfectly adequate to the mose perilous of wars? Is it nothing to have thus entitled herself to the confidence of other nations, and made her friendship an object to be sedulously sought after by every Power in Europe? Is it nothing for her Chief Magistrate; for that very Mr. Madison, whom our malignant and insolent writers and others marked out to be DEPOSED; is it nothing for Americans to have seen this their plain fellow citizen, with a salary of less than six thousand pounds a year, with no heralds, guards, or gilded coaches, conducting her affairs, through this trying season, with so much ability, so much firmness, and, at the same time, with such tenderness for liberty, as to refrain from a resort even to the mild law of his country against those who have made use of that liberty for purpose of the blackest and basest treason?"The last part refers to the attempt by certain New England assemblies to secede from the Union in protest against the war.
And thus the issue of 1783 was...(happy sigh) settled.

"Britain won the War of 1812. Foremost American authority on the War of 1812 Donald Hickey admits that:"

“But the United States failed to conquer Canada, and the maritime issues were not even mentioned in the peace treaty. By any reasonable measure, Republican war policy was a failure, and the United States actually lost the war–even if it has never acknowledged the fact.” Donald Hickey “Who Really Won the War of 1812?”

"After the Louisiana Purchase the Jeffersonianism desire to acquire the Floridas meant supporting Republican France and instilling hostility to Britain and her ally, Spain. Brown-nosing Bonaparte, the “ogre of Europe”, the US administration even refused to recognise the legitimacy of Ferdinand VII, usurped by Napoleon . The extent of the USA’s grubby dealings with Napoleon is covered in ‘The Pan-American Policy of Jefferson and Wilkinson’ by Isaac Cox."

"US ambitions of aggrandizement and conquest were directed against Canada. The evidence from sessions of 12th Congress, The Legislature of Massachusetts (June 1813), Article XI of the USA Articles of Confederation, territorial ambitions elsewhere and the proclamations demonstrate that conquest and annexation of British North America was the goal. If the USA had won then there wouldn’t be a Canada today."

“We shall drive the British from our continent. I therefore feel anxious not only to add the Floridas to the South, but the Canadas to the North of this empire.”
Felix Grundy, Speech, in Annals of Congress, 12th Cong., 1st Sess."

"But the USA failed to conquer Canada. They also failed to address any of the casus belli in the peace treaty, leaving British maritime belligerent rights intact. These same ‘rights’ saw the Royal Navy searching US ships in her blockade of Africa to stop the Atlantic Slave Trade. The Orders in Council of the Napoleonic era were repeated a century later by the Orders in Council of 1915, this time prohibiting US trade with Germany."

"So much for the American boast that conquest of Canada would be a “mere matter of marching” or that she won “freedom of the seas”.

“The Battle of New Orleans, although fought after Britain had signed and ratified the peace treaty, played a particularly important role in forging the myth of American victory” (page 316 'The War of 1812: A Forgotten Conflict')."

"As Hickey correctly observes, American ‘victory’ is a myth."

Though it resulted in a stalemate, the War of 1812 proved to be quite beneficial to the United State's nationalism and military might. Before the War of 1812, the United States was in no condition to wage a full fledged war; much less, land an invasion for a mass number of reasons. First of all, the United States suffered horrendous debt resulting from previous wars and restricted trade issues with France. This meant that the US military was drastically underfunded, badly lead, ill-equipped, and ill-trained. The US Navy was very low on ships and moral; most of America's war vessels were merchant vessels fitted with cannons and artillery, which paled in comparison to the military might of Great Britain's Royal Navy. Not to mention, the majority of America's public did not support the US military, and protested any such war with Great Britain, including America's invasion of Upper/Lower Canada. However, it was the US who first waged war on the British Empire. This declaration of war was influenced by prominent British transgressions against US trade with France, Impressment, and Native American induced proxy wars. Furthermore, The British Empire made several alliances to help aid their military offensives against the US in the War of 1812. The U S. found themselves fighting against - Spain, the United Kingdom, The Canadas, Tecumseh's Confederacy, Shawnee, Creek, Red Sticks, Ojibway, Chickamauga, Fox, Iroquois, Miami, Mingo, OttawaKickapoo, Delaware (Lenape), Mascouten, Potawatomi, Sauk, Wyandot ...etc.

A long summary of the War of 1812: begins with US suppression of multiple Indian rebellions, until British and Native Americans join forces; resulting in multiple US defeats; including - US naval defeats, settlements massacred by Indians, American retreat from Upper Canada, then capture of Detroit Michigan(early 1812) In 1813, the US military sought it's opportunity to recapture Detroit; as well as destroying Canada's capital of York and torching much of Ontario(Upper Canada) The US also managed to repress the Royal Navy until April 1814, As large numbers of British troops arrived, raiding Chesapeake Bay and eventually capturing Washington, D.C. ... After a severe Royal Navy defeat at Craney Island, On September 13(A major turning in the war) Fort McHenry withstood 25 hours of bombardment by the British Navy, causing British forces to leave the Chesapeake Bay and focus on capturing New Orleans. Towards the end of the war, the US military had strengthened to a degree which shifted Britain's military offensive towards a downward spiral; eventually, causing them to call for the peace treaty at Ghent, in direct response to America's victory at Plattsburgh New York. After the war's end, the British Empire failed in it's attempts to capture Louisiana at the Battle of New Orleans. Finally, the US Navy dispatched Britain's Royal Navy from America's national waters.

"it was the final action between British and American forces. The American gunnery was far more effective than the British, despite the two being virtually identical in strength. After exchanging both broadsides and musket fire, the British commander was killed and the British brig was too badly damaged to be salvaged and was set ablaze by the victors after the removal of its stores."

The unprovoked American attack on East India Company ship, 'Nautilus' was the last military action of the War of 1812, and resulted in a final American Naval victory over the British Empire ...

lol, lots of Americans like to pass the War of 1812 off as some sort of 'second war of independence' that they won. They started the war by invading Canada (albeit over genuine grievances), and got defeated.

The British goal wasn't "Oh, let's have another crack at those Yanks and bring them all back into the Empire". They weren't trying to take away America's independence. Like the Americans, once the war was underway their aim was to seize enough territory to force a peace more beneficial to them.

By the end of the war, neither side had achieved all their goals. The Treat of Ghent didn't address any of the American grievances (although they went away anyway when Napoleon was defeated), and everything went back to the way it was before. The Americans took more casualties than the British, and lost the last battle of the war (not New Orleans, but actually Fort Bowyer).

"The pressure brought to bear on America by the British blockade was exceedingly effective, but it was silent, and so historians have tended to forget it. They have chronicled with pride or regret according to their nationality, the capture of an occasional British ship by an American sloop, but they have paid little heed to the ceaseless strain on the American resources caused by the blockade. Its mere existence inflicted a direct material loss to the American people a hundredfold greater than the entire American navy was able to inflict on Great Britain from the beginning to the end of its gallant career in this war. The very fact that the workings of the blockade were ceaseless and almost universal makes it difficult to realise their importance. It told heavily against the coasting trade, though less heavily than against foreign commerce; and it revived an almost archaic industry, that of the waggoners, who travelled slowly, parallel with the coastline, to carry with an infinitely greater labour and expense the goods that had formerly gone in the sloops and schooners."—Theodore Roosevelt

The fact the precise opposite happened should tell you who really won.
Then the focus is thrown onto the British counter offensive into US territory and it's apparent "lack of success". For fighting what started as a defensive war only to end utterly repulsing the attackers and tearing a new arsehole right across the aggressors territory, that is categorically NOT failure. British troops were operating on US soil right upto the war's official and technical conclusion (Capture of Fort Bowyer). There was no kicking out, simply an exit after causing terrible damage to the aggressor. The fact that the US launched an offensive to start the war only to end up fighting a desperate defensive war as far South as New Orleans shows you who really won.

Common misconception #2: "The USN defeated the Royal Navy"
The US enjoyed some early frigate victories in the war against the stretched out British Naval Squadron operating out of Halifax. And later on had success attacking British whaling and the likes in the Pacific and near the Galapagos/ Western seaboard of South America.
This only happened for the wars first year. After the capture of the USS Chesapeake by the HMS Shannon a trend set and the British evened the score in frigate actions. The Royal Navy went on to impose a devastating economic and trade naval blockade on the US, thus wrecking the US economy. The raids conducted under the supervision of John Borlase Warren terrified the Chesapeake region and the British caught more prizes than the US.
Ventures like that of David Porter against British whaling ships in the Pacific were put to an end when his ships the USS Essex and USS Essex Junior were taken by James Hillyar on the HMS Phoebe and HMS Cherub.
The total effect on the British maritime economy by the War of 1812, with British whaling recovering well, was negligible and didn't amount to more than a scratch.

So who really won the war of 1812? It's simple. Let's review the facts and objectives at the war's beginning.
USObjt1. Invade Canada and successfully expel the British Empire  BritishObjective 1. Protect Canada for the Empire
USObjective2. End impressment of US sailors                                     BritishObjective 2. Protect and maintain trade.
USObjective3. Stop incursions or attacks by Native Americans

US OBJECTIVES

First and foremost, the US invasion of Canada. This was an abject failure, As we all know Canada is a separate country today with strong British ties. If that isn't already obvious then in brief, the US had various unsuccessful incursions into Canada that were repulsed, or so god awful they barley happened at all. For example Hull's retreat and subsequent loss at Fort Detroit (taken by Isaac Brock), the US defeat at Queenston Heights, and Dearborn's attempt further East. Other incursions occurred also. And all were repulsed were forced to withdraw. FAILURE 

Then the end of impressment. This reason is usually prioritized by some as an attempt to take attention off America's failure in Canada. Even Madison used it to counteract the US public eye landing on the US army's failure in Canada.  As the Napoleonic wars were drawing to a close the Admiralty ended impressment to sailors of ALL nationalities as the demand for sea-goers wasn't as high. The French threat was gone and The British Royal navy resumed business as usual as part of a wind down process after the victory of the coalition. The hundred days and then subsequent final defeat of Napoleon did not see a sudden surge or revival in the practice. It was ended due to strictly non American efforts and at a time of the ADMIRALTY'S choosing. No one else. So while it was beneficial to the US, it was no a victory for them as the end of it had nothing to do with them. FAILURE

As for the end of Native raids this was an issue that predated the war. Following minor battles and confrontations in the past, the US and the likes of Tecumseh's confederacy were more than willing to fight one another. This is understandable that the native Americans would be irritated by US expansionism. For example the dodgy Treaty of Fort Wayne exceeded disrespect for Tecumseh as about 3 million acres of Native ground was given to the US, without the consent of the US President and therefore US government. To say nothing of the bribery and legal loopholes that riddled not only this deal but previous ones. It also became evident that Tecumseh was being armed by the British following the discovery of British firearms following such a fore mentioned engagements. However, with that in mind, remember this quote,
"However, according to the U.S Army Center of Military History, the "land-hungry frontiersmen", with "no doubt that their troubles with the Indians were the result of British intrigue", exacerbated the problem by "[ circulating stories] after every Indian raid of British Army muskets and equipment being found on the field". Thus, "the westerners were convinced that their problems could best be solved by forcing the British out of Canada"."

The natives went to the British for protection. And the British saw an opportunity to create a Native American buffer state. However, it it worth remembering this certainly wasn't a huge priority for the British government. What was a secondary objective for the British was a primary one for the Natives. Unfortunately for Tecumseh's followers, their leader was killed early October 1813 and as a result his confederacy soon fell apart. The British, while not intending to take any part of the US for themselves, still considered putting forth a native American Confederacy nation at Ghent. This quote sums up some key points, but has some misconceptions such as "long standing goal" and how much interest the British showed in it.
"The British had the long-standing goal of creating a large "neutral" Indian state that would cover much of Ohio, Indiana, and Michigan. They made the demand as late as the fall of 1814 at the peace conference, but lost control of western Ontario in 1813 at key battles on and around Lake Erie. These battles destroyed the Indian confederacy which had been the main ally of the British in the region, and which would make up the proposed neutral state. Although the area remained under British or British-allied Indians' control until the end of the war, it became a less practicable idea. At American insistence, and with higher priorities, the British dropped the demands". SUCCESS
However this is often VASTLY over inflated, along with the intentions and desires the British had on the US. The story is ALTOGETHER less simple, as demonstrated in the knowledgeable side note below. ..
Side note: Courtesy of E Richardson:

The French had a peaceful relationship with natives because of their generosity. Yearly gifts (Beads, iron goods, Guns ammunition Blankets)  of "tribute" (For lack of a better word as these were obligations) became huge gatherings of many tribes as the promises of alliance & peace were renewed.
The French Indian war saw the French colonists submit to British rule as formalized by the treaty how ever Natives never accepted that France had the right to cede territory that belonged to them as they had never submitted to French rule & saw the French colonies as more of a lease. So long as France continued paying tribute the colonies were unmolested.
The British assuming they were clear title holders neglected the "Gifts" which resulted in Pontiac's Rebellion. This war was a nightmarishly horrible & ended in a stalemate. Amherst was called back to Britain the gifts resumed, now with Britain being the giver & the Royal Proclamation 1763 saw the limiting of colonial growth as Natives were acknowledged to have rights to their own lands. This was the first time any European power legally acknowledged this right. (Its also the reason these events are still a inflammatory topic to Natives as we are fighting in court battles right now for rights we had granted to us then
Supposedly this could be seen as the beginning of "the long-standing goal of creating a large "neutral" Indian state" but the American colonies had not even rebelled yet so this wasn't a buffer to anything, it was a compromise for peace.
Part of the reason Britain didn't mind ceding the region to the Americans after their revolution was because Britain only had a precarious hold on it in the first place. When the Americans refused to honor the treaty of Paris 1783 article 5 about compensating Loyalist for property the rebels had stolen Britain used the relationship with Natives to back Little Turtle. It wasn't spite, it was because the USA wasn't honoring the treaty. It certainly wasn't because Britain cared about Natives. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northwest_Indian_War
Keep in mind this was where Tecumseh came in to the picture.
When the USA finally paid the debt & signed the Jay treaty 1793 fact is the newly formed British/USA relationship was vastly more profitable then the British/Native relationship... and the British abandoned their Native allies to their fate at the Battle of Fallen Timbers. Tecumseh was there. Didn't leave with warm fuzzy feelings about British.
Britain continued to give gifts rather then have Natives attack British settlements in the west as the Napoleonic war heated up but also did everything in its power to avoid antagonizing their new trading partner who made no secret of their feelings towards sharing North America with Britain. While Tecumseh began building his confederation around his brother's Tenskwatawa teachings.
Its very important to realize those teachings were hostile to all White Settlements not just American as they focused squarely upon Native dependence upon European tech. The Difference being the British continued honoring the treaties while the Americans not only ignored them but were actively hostile to Natives.
Tecumseh didn't agree to an alliance with British till after Prophetstown was destroyed by Americans. The Americans attacked & destroyed all food stores just as winter was coming. So Britain got its ally for little more then food & iron pots so that they wouldn't stave.
Mind you if the USA had not destroyed Prophetstown Natives could have fielded easily ten times the number they did at Detroit. The Success of Detroit quickly brought that number back up again.
As Britain entered negotiations at Ghent they wanted to restore the situation before the war. They had to at least try to get recognition of a Native state by Americans as Natives were still helping with the defense of Canada & ignoring the issue completely would likely have resulted in another war between Natives & British settlements there.

BRITISH OBJECTIVES

The British protection of Canada was obviously a success. I refer you to the comment addressing US aims of conquest. This was a British victory. OUTSTANDING SUCCESS.

British objective of maintaining trade and the seaways. As a matter of fact, US privateers did well. Far better than the US navy in fact. The US privateers took 1,300 to the USN's 254 in captures. And this is commendable in light of their relatively short relationship with the sea. However British trade was overall not greatly damaged and the British took 1400 US ships as prizes in the war. The British economy wasn't greatly damaged. The huge and powerful maritime economy made sure of that, only 7% being greatly affected. The same however can't be same for the US, with their maritime economy crippled as a result of the British blockade. "The parlous American economy was thrown into chaos with prices soaring and unexpected shortages causing hardship". There were NO such issues in Britain. On top of this, various US naval ships were bottled up in port and when they tried to escape they were captured (the Chesapeake and President). SUCCESS

1/3 US Objectives achieved, beaten by 2/2 British Objectives achieved. Therefore, we must conclude that the British Empire won this conflict. ﻿

Fred finally got Jacquie admitted to St. Joseph's in Hamilton, regarded as the best mental health facility in Ontario. Jacquie's mother and Fred met with one of the two resident psychiatrists that always dealt with Jacquie's admissions. They pleaded, begged and cried.

Traditionally, achievement of war aims names the victor in war. The US wished to annex the Canadas (North and South) which it failed to do. Great Britain wished to repel an American invasion into it's crown territories, which it was able to achieve, but it did not wish to take control of America again as it would have been economically unviable due to the debts it amassed during the Napoleonic Wars.

So to this end, Britain did win the War of 1812, however neither side (aside from the Indians of course) actually suffered any serious repercussions and the war itself did not have have a significant direct impact, although it did indirectly bring many benefits to the US.

I don't understand why everyone keeps saying that America lost. It is draw in most cases. The British goals were met that is true. But the British were trying ultimately destroy America. They didn't succeed in this and America took back all the provinces they lost. But the main thing that defines it as a draw is. THEY SIGNED A PEACE TREATY. PEACE TREATY. Peace Treaty means the end of an armed conflict. And the terms of victory for Britain and America were different. The British goals were achieved but the terms of condition for Britain were to destroy America by completely conquering it. The American goals were to annex Canada. That of course was a complete failure that I admit. But the British goal of halting American expansion was failed even when america was still under their control. Americans were going across the Allegheny Mountains despite the pleas of the British not to. During the War of 1812 the Americans were still expanding against the Native Americans. So the British goal of halting American territory was a failure. Also the British also tried to take over the Great Lakes. That was a failure. But really if you look at the smaller goals,not just the bigger goals you realize that basically there was a even amount of failure and defeat. But again it comes back to if you make a Peace Treaty the side that ultimately wins is of course the one with the most successes but in this case it was pretty much an even battle. At the start no but at the end it was a stalemate.

I'd also like to address the Canadian issue.  I know some Canadian commenters say this war was a win for Canada, but I cannot really accept this because Canada did not yet exist as a nation.  They're welcome to feel pride, God knows we Americans do, but I find the pro-Canadian argument to be as hollow as declaring American victory in the French & Indian War.  Furthermore, I find it odd that everyone remembers the burning of Washington, yet few people remember the burning of York (modern day Toronto) -the provincial capital of Upper Canada during the war.  The way I see it, the burning of Canada's & America's capitals makes us even-steven.

I personally call the war of 1812 a draw between an upstart America & a war weary British Empire.  Neither side gained much on paper, but both sides certainly came to an understanding that I think benefited our great nations in the long run.

Since I was a child I always liked to envision the US and Canada as half-brothers; the US being bred from their mother England and father Spain, while Canada born of England and father France.
Canada is the "good" son who has kept in touch with it's mother and never created waves in the community.
US is the young upstart, who rebelled in it's youth to be it's "own person" (so to speak), and continues to try maintain it's reputation as someone you shouldn't fuck with.
The US is the older, tougher brother, where Canada, although bigger in size, is more the kinder, gentler young brother.
They've had their differences, and even come to blows when they were growing up, with Canada showing at a early age that he won't be bullied, but they've resolved their major differences.
Aside from occasionally picking on and name calling, they know that they can trust one another to have each other's back and rely on the brotherhood they share.
In the future they may have a "falling-out", but for now, despite their current money problems, they remain Great North American Brothers.

Oh, and Mexico is the US's other brother, whom he keeps trying to disassociate with, trying to put up walls in their relationship to keep it out of it's life, because the US thinks Mexico is stealing money from him.

On December 24, 1814, the members of the British and American negotiating teams signed and affixed their individual seals to the document. It didn't end the war itself—that required formal ratification by their governments, which came in February 1815. The treaty released all prisoners and restored all captured lands and ships. Returned to the United States were approximately 10,000,000 acres (40,000 km2) of territory, near Lakes Superior and Michigan, and in Maine. American-held areas of Upper Canada (present-day Ontario) were returned to British control. The treaty thus made no significant changes to the prewar boundaries, although the U.S. did gain territory from Spain. Britain promised to return the freed black slaves that they had taken. In actuality, a few years later Britain instead paid the United States $1,204,960 for them.

I don't see why people often say that Britain attempted to destroy America. That was simply not one of Britain's military objectives. In fact the british government was looking for a resolution to hostilities from the start of the war and made numerous advances to the American side in the early days of the war. The attacks on washington, baltimore and New Orleans were not full blown invasions set on ending the US state. They were more "raids" launched as part of Admiral Cockburn's war against the US economy and privateer effort. The assault of Baltimore was an attempt to crush the privateer effort once and for all and at the same time inflict devastating losses on the US economy. The burning of Washington can be see as more an act of revenge for the US declaration of war rather that the beginning of an invasion. This theory is supported  by the fact that after the British torched the city they withdrew north towards their territory rather than pushed further south.

pijef, since I can't reply to your posts directly this will have to do.

You see before commencing the war of 1812 the American military outlined some objectives for their campaign. One of the most important was the conquest of Canada, not the occupation of some northern territory. In dispatches the war in Canada was called a mission of emancipation. However things did not go well for the US and every single invasion failed. It did not matter how many battles in Canada the Us won the fact remains that the invasions were repelled and often decisively. Another mistake you made was classifying the Battle of Queenston heights as an American victory. It wasn't, American casualties were substantially higher and at the end of the battle the British controlled the heights while the Americans were in full retreat. I fail to see how you can insist that it was an American victory.

Further more the US navy also suffered major losses such as the USS Chesapeak and the USS President. Towards the end of the war the British imposed an effective blockade which restricted the movement of the US navy. In fact most US ships never left port due to fear of the overwhelming British strength. The privateer effort was also crushed and losses amongst British trade ships were minimal, less than 0.1% of all British merchantmen were captured by American privateers and a third of all the ships that were captured were recaptured before they reached port.

Another area where America suffered greatly was in the economy. US state revenue fell from 7 million at the start of the war to around 400,000 at the conclusion of hostilities. The British blockade was so effective that it cut off almost all American overseas trade leading to disastrous economic problems.

American sailors were usually paid better and treated better than British sailors.  This led to British sailors jumping ship and joining American crews.  The British in return would grab as many sailors as needed from American ships by claiming they were all British (also they would threaten to open fire on the American ship if it refused.)

The American Navy (and the military in general,) was horribly outgunned during the war, both outnumbered as stated but also had no battleships, called ships of the line at the time.  The US Navy was based around Heavy Frigates, who operated independently, while the British used large ships for landings and blockades and smaller Frigates to attack merchants.  This is why almost every naval battle (Except the battles of the Lake Erie, where small fleets of small ships fought,) was a 1 on 1 Frigate Duel, where the US could win or run at its pleasure.

The people who lived in British North America were known as Canadian's back then as the colonies were called Upper and Lower Canada. Just like people who lived in America (even though many of them were British citizens were identified as Americans). There were also a lot of American's that lived and worked in BNA who didn't want a war pushed upon them. When the American forces invaded the colonies in BNA it forced many American's to choose sides. And there were victories over U.S. forces. The early part of the war was a complete disaster for American forces because of poor tactics and organization. U.S. forces were defeated in Michigan Territory and the Battle of Queenston Heights repelled the American invasion of the Niagara peninsula. The victory at the Battle of Bladensburg opened the way for the capture and burning of Washington DC. Also there were many successes by combined British, Canadian, and Aboriginal militias along the border regions that repelled American expansion into BNA. Ultimately both sides didn't succeed to expand each other's territory, it just reinforced the geographic borders.

The claim that no territory changed hands isn't technically true, we took an island that had an abandoned naval base on it from Canada.

The Battle of Baltimore began on September 13, 1814

The treaty was signed on December 24, 1814. 

The Battle of New Orleans was fought on January 8th, 1815.

Baltimoreans also struck at the British directly. Swiftly sailing schooners seized British merchant ships and transported limited cargoes to foreign ports. Other cities followed the practice; however, Baltimore alone accounted for about 30 percent of all British merchant ships captured by the U.S. during the war. From this, Baltimore earned the nickname "nest of pirates."

The British blockade of shipping, particularly on the Chesapeake Bay, forced the nation from its dependence on trade with foreign markets toward westward expansion to the interior of its own continent. Additionally, the American victory in the campaign forced other powerful countries to recognize and respect the United States' maritime rights.

Baltimore's trade and commercial prowess made the region a target for the British invasion, affecting trade patterns and the future of Anglo-American commerce. In the first months of the war, the depredations of private armed vessels, or privateers, many from Baltimore shipyards, prompted the British Admiralty to declare the entire east coast under naval blockade.

I just think its really interesting that Britain built a 1st rate, a colossally expensive endeavour designed for pitched battles on a lake, no matter how big, highlighting the importance of that lake to Britain. I included the numbers because sloop, frigate and first rate doesnt exactly mean a lot to most people.

As a cursory side note I learnt this (and read more) through Empire Total War. Games facilitating learning :D

The war of 1812 also hosts the only 1st rate ever to be launched and never go to sea.

HMS St Lawrence laid down and launch in 1814 never saw combat and was decommissioned only a year later but despite this she effectively ended the battle for control of Lake Ontario due to the inability of the US to field something even remotely comparable. For comparison St Lawrance had 112 guns ~700 personal, the standard frigate (the primary "big ship" of the lakes) had ~35 guns and less than 400 personal.

It was called Canada before 1867.
What happened in 1867 was, the Union of Canada (a single colony including Canada West and Canada East) and the separate colonies of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick were joined in a federal constitutional regime.  The Union was divided into Ontario and Quebec, which had been the separate colonies of Upper and Lower Canada before 1841.
When someone in London in 1812 talked about Canada, they were talking about a smaller place than it is now, but it was still Canada.

The battle at Fort Detroit was much more interesting than presented. Isaac Brock and Tecumseh had 1300 men, mostly militia to Hull's 2000 soldiers. Brock dressed the militia in the British uniforms to intimidate Hull. When they reached Fort Detroit Tecumseh marched his men in front of the gates in a continuous loop. Hull freaked out and surrendered without ever firing a shot. He was put on trial in the US for his surrender and sentenced to death. He was pardoned before being executed.

The War of 1812 also saw the first use of the term "Canadian" among the English settlers there. Up until the sacking & razing of York it had been used exclusively by the French. The destruction of the city showed that the Americans didn't respect the property rights of the inhabitants, prompting the fence-sitters to join the militia & differentiate themselves with a local name.

Also, the British were careful not to destroy any private property in Washington; they didn't want things to escalate.
